article.headline: Hut Group shares soar more than 30% on market debut in Londonâs biggest ever tech IPO
article.body: Shares in The Hut Group soared more than 30% in the online health and beauty retailerâs first day of trading on Wednesday in London, as it swept away corporate governance concerns to become the U.K.âs biggest ever technology initial public offering. The Hut Group, which will trade under the stock market ticker THG, helps sell retail brands, including Lookfantastic, skin care group ESPA, and sports nutrition player Myprotein.com. It sold 376 million shares at 500 pence each to raise Â£1.88 billion pounds, valuing the company at Â£5.4 billion ($7 billion). The stock market debut nets The Hut Group Â£920 million ($1.2 billion) that will be used to pay down the companyâs debt, which has risen sharply in recent years. Net debt increased to Â£514 million at the end of 2019 from Â£294 million at the end of 2018, according to CMC Markets. Shareholders, led by founder Matthew Moulding, will share gross proceeds of Â£961 million ($1.24 billion). âI am delighted that THG has received such strong support from some of the worldâs largest investors, which means we have been able to achieve a highly successful offer of shares in the company,â said Chief Executive Matthew Moulding. Shares in THG were trading close to 30% up at 645 pence in early morning London trading. The IPO will provide a welcome boost to the European market for new listings, which has seen a slump in volumes during the coronavirus pandemic. It is the largest ever tech IPO in London based on market capitalization at listing, and the second largest tech IPO by capital raised, after Worldpay raised Â£2.5 billion in October 2015. Tech is now the fourth largest sector on the LSE, representing around 11% of the total market capitalization of London-listed companies, almost quadrupling in size over the last five years. Read:A new breed of tech IPOs may give the stock market reason to party like itâs 1999 THG, which is based in Manchester, has come under scrutiny from investors who have raised concerns over the structure of the deal, which sees Moulding continuing as both chairman and chief executive of the company and retaining control via a âfounder shareâ â meaning he will retain control for three years. The company says this will help guard against potential hostile takeover bids in the future. âIt is intended to permit the holder to deter an unwelcome acquisition of the Company that would not, in the holderâs opinion, deliver sufficient value,â the IPO prospectus states. The structure means that THG wonât be eligible for a premium listing and wonât be able to join the FTSE 100, despite being big enough for the blue-chip index of leading shares. Under an unusual incentive scheme, Moulding, who founded the company in 2004, could also be in line to receive bonus payouts of as much as Â£700 million if THGâs market value reaches Â£7.25 billion within three years. Russ Mould, investment director at AJ Bell, said that while the IPO might say more about how dormant the U.K. market has been in recent years than it does about The Hut Group, it still reflects strong appetite for the story, with lots of fund managers âclamoring to get a piece of the actionâ at the 500p issue price. âMuch of the excitement around the stock surrounds its Ingenuity e-commerce fulfillment platform. In the same way Ocadoâs online groceries solution is sold to third party supermarkets â The Hut is signing up the likes of NestlÃ© NESN, +0.36% and Procter & Gamble PG, +0.89% Â to Ingenuity and this is seen as the big growth opportunity for the business,â Mould said. THG currently employs 7,000 people and has to grow to 10,000 in next few years. The company has risen from a company with Â£1 million of revenue in 2004 to more than Â£1.1 billion in 2019. BlackRock, Henderson Global Investors, Merian and the Qatar Investment Authority agreed to buy Â£565 million of the shares offered. KKR, the private equity group that became a shareholder in THG in 2014, sold its entire holding worth Â£448 million. JPMorgan, Citi, Barclays and Goldman Sachs acted as global coordinators on the flotation, while HSBC, Jefferies and Numis were mandates as joint bookrunners.
